lessons.title: Lesson #1 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, we can easily integrate input fields to capture user data. It begins with a simple input setup.

Let's start by adding an input field to our component.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, we can easily integrate input fields to capture user data. To do that we use the self-closing input element.

Start by adding an input field to our component.

Make sure to pick <, followed by input, and finally />.

lessons.title: s
lessons.interactiveContent:
Before we can expect the user to type something in, we should tell them what to type in.

Add a placeholder variable and assign it a string value.

Make sure to pick placeholder, followed by =, and finally "Enter username...".

lessons.title: s - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We need to maintain the input value within the component state as the user types in the input field.

Create an inputValue state variable to initialize and update the state of the input.

Make sure to pick const followed by inputValue and then setInputValue, useState, "".

lessons.title: s - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We create a function that takes one argument called event to handle the state changes.

The event is an object that contains information about the user's interaction, allowing us to access the updated value.

Make sure to pick handleChange, followed by event.

lessons.title: s - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The input element has a onChange event handler that triggers whenever the user types.

To update the state when input changes, we call our own event handler handleChange when the onChange handler is called.

Make sure to pick onChange, followed by handleChange.

lessons.title: s - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Inside this function, we update the state with the new input value.

Update the state variable with the value from event.target.value.

Make sure to pick setInputValue followed by event and then .target, .value.

lessons.title: s - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Once it's saved in a state variable, we can access the value easily.

Display the input value below the input field as the user types.

Make sure to pick {, followed by inputValue, and finally }.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which attribute of an input element is used to display a short hint or instruction?

placeholdertitlelabelalt

Make sure to pick placeholder.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create an input element with a placeholder and an event handler.

Make sure to pick input followed by placeholder and then "Type a movie name...", onChange, handleChange.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
What concept allows React components to store and update user input?

StatePropsLifecycle methodsJSX

Make sure to pick State.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a state variable color and use it to set the color of the p element. (Try entering red, green, or blue).

Make sure to pick color, followed by useState, and finally color.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
When using the onChange event in an input element, which argument is passed to the event handler function?

eventinputchangeaction

Make sure to pick event.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code to show a short message when the input's length exceeds a certain limit.

Make sure to pick input followed by input and then .length, > 5.

lessons.title: Lesson #16
lessons.interactiveContent:
Access the input field's input and use it to update the state variable.

Make sure to pick event followed by . and then target, ., value.
